speaker: James
text: The US-Taiwan trade deal in February 2026. Twenty-five billion dollars in corporate investment pledges for American semiconductor and AI production. That's a stunning figure, isn't it? A 15% tariff. Unthinkable a decade ago, truly.

speaker: Elena
text: It’s not just stunning, James, it's a complete repudiation. The article describes it as 'mercantilist bargain dressed in the language of free trade'. That's spot on. The orthodoxy is dead, isn't it?

speaker: James
text: Absolutely. For forty years, the West was told manufacturing didn't matter. Services, finance, the 'knowledge economy' were everything. Making physical things was for countries with cheap labour. That idea has been thoroughly debunked.

speaker: Elena
text: And the cost of that delusion has been enormous. You look at the 2.5 million jobs reshored or created in the US since 2010 – 2023 and 2024 seeing record annual totals. It shows the scale of what was lost, and what's now being frantically rebuilt.

speaker: James
text: Indeed. The article rightly calls the period from 1980 to 2015 an aberration. Protectionism, state subsidies, industrial policy – this is the historical norm for any nation that ever became a great power. From the English East India Company to Hamilton's America.

speaker: Elena
text: Hamilton’s 'Report on Manufactures' in 1791. A foundational document that explicitly rejected Adam Smith. He understood that a young nation couldn't compete, and would remain a raw materials exporter without protection.

speaker: James
text: Precisely. The US became the most protectionist major economy for 150 years, with tariffs often between 35% and 50%. And it went from a marginal agricultural economy to the largest industrial power on Earth. Not a coincidence.

speaker: Elena
text: Friedrich List saw it too, didn't he? Britain 'kicking away the ladder' – using protectionism to get to the top, then advocating free trade to keep others down. It’s a cynical but accurate reading of history.

speaker: James
text: Utterly. Britain only became a champion of free trade once the Industrial Revolution gave it an unbeatable advantage. Free trade, in that context, was a weapon, not a philosophy.

speaker: Elena
text: So, if protectionism built every major power, why did the West abandon it after 1945?

speaker: James
text: The Cold War. A strategic subsidy, as the article puts it. America traded manufacturing jobs for military alliances. Japan, South Korea, West Germany – they all got preferential access to the US market. Geopolitics trumped economics.

speaker: Elena
text: Right, and it made sense then. But the problem was, the Soviet Union collapsed in '91, and the strategy didn't. It became an article of faith. The Washington Consensus. Fukuyama's 'end of history' nonsense.

speaker: James
text: And the admission of China to the WTO in 2001, on the assumption that trade would liberalise its political system. A catastrophic miscalculation.

speaker: Elena
text: Catastrophic is right. Western companies rushed in, transferred technology, built factories. China didn’t just make cheap toys; it systematically moved up the value chain, backed by massive state subsidies and IP theft.

speaker: James
text: By 2018, China was the world’s largest manufacturer and exporter. The theory of comparative advantage hadn't just failed; it had been weaponised against the nations that believed in it. A point we've explored extensively in our 'China Has Many Of The Characteristics Of An Emerging Colonial Power' piece.

speaker: Elena
text: And the consequences of our deindustrialisation are now undeniable. Europe couldn't deliver a million artillery shells to Ukraine. Its combined GDP ten times Russia's, but a fraction of its military output. It wasn't money; it was capacity. The factories were gone.

speaker: James
text: Exactly. The strategic implications are terrifying. During COVID, America couldn't produce enough surgical masks. The richest nation on Earth dependent on China for basic medical supplies. Imagine a serious conflict.

speaker: Elena
text: It's the ultimate 'Crisis: Or An Explanation On The Origins Of The Decline Of The West' scenario playing out. We outsourced our ability to sustain ourselves. Thomas Sowell's point about foregone alternatives rings so true.

speaker: James
text: The cheap television from China had hidden costs: millions of jobs lost, communities hollowed out, skills that disappeared, strategic dependencies created. Those never appeared on the price tag.

speaker: Elena
text: So, the return of the state factory isn't a policy fad, it's a correction. Tariffs up to 100% on some Chinese goods. The CHIPS Act, the Inflation Reduction Act. Billions channelled into domestic manufacturing.

speaker: James
text: Europe is following, albeit more slowly. The EU's Chips Act, Germany talking 'strategic autonomy.' It's a recognition of reality. And technology is the critical enabler.

speaker: Elena
text: The disappearing labour cost advantage. If a robot-staffed factory costs roughly the same in Ohio as it does in Guangdong, then why on earth would you build it halfway across the world? This is what we’ve discussed in 'Robotics And Slavery' and 'The Fusion of Revolutionary Technologies'.

speaker: James
text: Precisely. AI and robotics are rapidly eliminating that differential. Morgan Stanley predicts 2026 as the inflection point, with companies first automating existing facilities, then building new greenfield sites domestically.

speaker: Elena
text: So, the 2020s to 2040s will look like the 19th century again? Tariffs, subsidies, state-directed investment. Call it 'strategic autonomy' or 'friend-shoring', it’s mercantilism by another name.

speaker: James
text: Absolutely. And the nations that rebuild their manufacturing base will become stronger, more resilient. They can arm their militaries, supply their hospitals, create a virtuous cycle of skilled workers, education, innovation.

speaker: Elena
text: A virtuous cycle that China has been running for thirty years while the West was patting itself on the back for its service economy. That's a brutal observation.

speaker: James
text: It is. And the alternative is clear: become like late Rome. Wealthy on paper, but dependent on others for everything. Outsourced military, outsourced agriculture. Vulnerable to any disruption.

speaker: Elena
text: Rome didn't fall because it was poor, but because it outsourced its core capabilities. That's a chilling parallel for any modern state that forgot how to make things.

speaker: James
text: Indeed. The Ricardian theory of comparative advantage won't disappear from textbooks, but it will be taught as a historical curiosity. A theory for a brief, unusual period when one group of nations was so dominant they could pretend the rules didn't apply.

speaker: Elena
text: But the rules always apply. They just took forty years to reassert themselves, often at immense cost. The factories are coming back.

speaker: James
text: The crucial question, then, isn't if, but which nations will build them fast enough. And what happens to those that don't?
